Author: flipperplz
Content: To go more into detail on this - originally enforce was made with optional semicolons (similar to languages like kotlin) over time bi has added more and more to the language. At a certain point a language becomes too ambiguous to not contain any semicolons without some drawbacks. As a work around ';' is its own statement. Thinking of semicolons as optional will lead to problems (they are only optional in certain cases). For things like unbraced if/else (class and methods can be unbraced too but this is terrible convention) the semicolon statement tells the parser when it ends.

Author: flipperplz
Content: This is why a single script with 200 semicolons can get compiled perfectly
